find: find: search for files in a directory hierarchy. Use 'man find' for more details. Key options: -name (find by name, e.g., '*.txt'), -mtime (find by modification time, e.g., -mtime -1 for <1 day), -exec (execute command, e.g., -exec rm {} \;), -delete (delete found files). Use -print0 with xargs -0 for safety. Remember to escape wildcards like '*' or use quotes: -name "*.log"
sort: sort: sort lines of text files. Key options: -t (field separator, e.g., -t','), -k (key definition, e.g., -k1,2 for sorting on first to second field, -k2 for second field). Use 'man sort' for more details.
awk:
awk - pattern scanning and processing language.
Example: awk [OPTIONS] 'program' [FILE...]
Key concepts: -F (field separator), $N (Nth field), NF (number of fields), NR (record number). Conditions (e.g., $1 == "value", $0 ~ /regex/), actions { print $0 }, BEGIN/END blocks. Loop through fields: for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) print $i. Use 'man awk' for more details.
sed:
sed - stream editor for filtering and transforming text.
Example: sed [OPTION]... 'script' [INPUTFILE...]
Key commands: s (substitute, e.g., s/old/new/g). Use -E or -r for extended regex. Capture groups (...) and backreferences (\1, \2) in replacement string. Use 'man sed' for details.
head: head: output the first part of files. Use 'man head' for details. Key option: -n (number of lines).
tail: tail: output the last part of files. Use 'man tail' for details. Key option: -n (number of lines).
uniq: uniq: report or omit repeated lines. By default, uniq filters adjacent matching lines. Use 'man uniq' for details. Key options: -c (count), -d (only print duplicate lines), -u (only print unique lines).
wc: wc: print newline, word, and byte counts for each file. Use 'man wc' for details. Key options: -l (lines), -w (words), -c (bytes), -m (characters).
ls:
ls - list directory contents.
Example: ls [OPTION]... [FILE]...
Key options: -l (long listing), -a (all files including hidden), -h (human readable sizes), -t (sort by modification time), -r (reverse order for sorting).
cut:
cut - remove sections from each line of files.
Example: cut OPTION... [FILE]...
Key options: -d (delimiter), -f (fields), -c (characters).
grep:
grep - searches for PATTERNS in each FILE.
Example: grep [OPTIONS] PATTERN [FILE...].
Key options: -i (ignore case), -v (invert match), -r (recursive), -n (line numbers), -c (count matches), -C N (N lines of context).
rm:
rm - remove files or directories.
Example: rm [OPTION]... FILE...
Key options: -r (recursive for directories), -f (force, ignore nonexistent files). NOTE: In this tool, 'rm' runs in a safe dry-run mode unless used with find -delete!
ping:
ping - send ICMP ECHO_REQUEST to network hosts.
Example: ping [OPTION]... HOST
Key options (Linux): -c (count), -i (interval). For Windows, -n (count), -w (timeout).
mv:
mv - move (rename) files.
Example: mv [OPTION]... SOURCE DESTINATION
Key options: -i (interactive, prompt before overwrite), -u (update, move only when source is newer).
xargs:
xargs - build and execute command lines from standard input.
Example: find . -print0 | xargs -0 rm
Key options: -0 (null-terminated input, for use with find -print0), -I {} (replace occurrences of {} with input lines).
